article.title: Effect of electron correlations on the electronic structure and phase stability of FeSe upon lattice expansion

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the upper panel of Figure 1 represent?
choices: The electronic band structure of FeSe.
The total energy of FeSe as a function of lattice constant.
The magnetic moment of FeSe as a function of lattice constant.
The density of states of FeSe at different temperatures.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the different colored lines in Figure 1?
choices: They represent different theoretical methods used in the calculations.
They show the effect of temperature on the total energy and magnetic moment.
They illustrate the variation of results with different exchange-correlation functionals.
They depict the behavior of FeSe under different external pressures.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is being illustrated by the arrows in the upper panel of Figure 3?
choices: The shift in the Fermi level with increasing Coulomb interaction (U).
The change in the magnetic moment of Fe atoms with increasing U.
The evolution of specific electronic bands with increasing U.
The change in the lattice constant with increasing U.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be concluded from the comparison of DFT and DFT+DMFT results in Figure 3?
choices: DFT accurately predicts the electronic structure and magnetic properties of FeSe.
DFT+DMFT provides a more accurate description of FeSe compared to DFT alone.
Both DFT and DFT+DMFT predict a similar evolution of electronic bands with increasing U.
DFT+DMFT fails to capture the experimentally observed increase in local magnetic moment with lattice expansion.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the different colors in the top row of Figure 5 represent?
choices: The different orbitals contributing to the electronic structure.
The Fermi surfaces of FeSe at different temperatures.
The Brillouin zone of FeSe at different lattice constants.
The effect of spin-orbit coupling on the electronic band structure.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the red rectangle in Figure 6?
choices: It highlights the region of lattice constant where FeSe exhibits superconductivity.
It marks the critical region associated with the change in orbital character and effective mass.
It indicates the range of lattice constant where the magnetic moment of FeSe is maximum.
It shows the lattice constant at which the structural transition from tetragonal to orthorhombic phase occurs.
